symptoms: Powdery mildew on cherry presents as a white to gray powdery growth on leaves, stems, and fruit, potentially causing leaf distortion and reduced fruit quality.
remedies: Prune infected branches to improve air circulation. Apply neem oil every 7-14 days as a natural fungicide. Use sulfur-based fungicides preventatively. Spray with potassium bicarbonate solutions to disrupt fungal growth. Ensure good air circulation around trees. Remove and destroy fallen leaves and infected fruit. Water at the base of the tree to avoid wetting foliage. Select cherry varieties with powdery mildew resistance. Apply a copper-based fungicide early in the season. Monitor trees regularly for early signs of infection.
